title: An oscillation-based technique for degradation monitoring of sensing and actuation electrodes within microfluidic systems.

abstract: There is significant interest in the use of electrodes for sensing or actuation in bio-fluidic microsystems. Within these systems high levels of reliability are crucial and complimented by requirements for extremely low probabilities of false positive and false negatives. This paper extends previous work on impedance and oscillation based condition monitoring of electrode arrays by investigating the application of oscillation built-in self-test to microfluidic based electrodes for conductance measurements and a system level implementation for monitoring multiple electrodes on-line

fullText:
J Electron Test : DOI 10.1007/s10836-011-5203-1   Page 1 
 
An Oscillation-based Technique for Degradation Monitoring of Sensing and 
Actuation Electrodes within Microfluidic Systems 
 
Q. Al-Gayem • A. Richardson • H. Liu • N. Burd 
 
Abstract There is significant interest in the use of 
electrodes for sensing or actuation in bio-fluidic 
microsystems. Within these systems high levels of 
reliability are crucial and complimented by requirements 
for extremely low levels of false positive and false 
negatives. This paper extends previous work on impedance 
and oscillation based condition monitoring of electrode 
arrays by investigating the application of oscillation built-
in self-test to a microfluidic based electrodes for 
conductance measurements and a system level 
implementation for monitoring multiple electrodes on-line. 
 
Keywords Embedded test • Built-in self-test • Bio-fluidics 
• Microfluidics 
 
Responsible Editor: H. Stratigopoulos 
Q. Al-Gayem • A. Richardson • N. Burd  
Centre for Microsystems Engineering, Lancaster University, 
Lancaster, UK 
LA1 4YR 
URL: http://www.engineering.lancs.ac.uk/microsystems/ 
 
Q. Al-Gayem 
e-mail: q.al-gayem@lancaster.ac.uk 
 
A. Richardson 
e-mail: a.richardson@lancaster.ac.uk 
 
N. Burd 
e-mail: n.burd@lancaster.ac.uk 
 
H. Liu 
Moor Instruments Ltd, Axminster, UK 
 
 
 
 
1. Introduction 
 
Microfluidic systems are an emerging technology that has 
the potential to realise the required fluidic transport, bio 
chemical detection and control functions capable of 
improved detection resolution and accuracy, mixing 
efficiency and reaction speed within a single miniturised 
portable instrument for bio-diagnostic and bio-synthesis 
applications. The market sectors of specific interest 
include medical diagnostics, industrial control, 
environmental monitoring and pharmacology. Examples 
are DNA extraction from blood, detection of pathogens, 
e.g. genetically modified organisms (GMO’s) or allergens 
and the replacement of animal testing.  In most cases, the 
value of this work is derived from the ability to generate 
enhanced measurements from extremely small samples 
(few ml) at low cost. 
The use of microfluidics in molecular biology has already 
been shown to offer benefits such as improved sensitivity 
and speed of analysis. An example here is a charge based 
capacitive biosensor for bacteria growth monitoring 
(BGM) presented in [1]. The sensor chip is implemented in 
a CMOS process in order to show the applicability of the 
proposed on-chip capacitive technique for BGM purposes. 
Another example is an integrated microfluidic-fibre optic 
device for the detection of agglutination for blood type 
cross-matching proposed and described by [2]. The device 
consists of a straight microfluidic channel through which a 
reacted red blood cell suspension flows through a syringe 
pump based actuation system. 
Electrodes are core components in both continuous and 
droplet fluidic flow microsystems. The use of electrodes as 
sensors has already shown in [3] where microelectrodes 
arrays (MEA) have been used as a cell-biosensor with 
separated neuronal cell cultures to study the signal 
processing of neural networks and to detect neurotoxins. 
There are also other applications for MEA in the fields of 
neurobiology and cardiac electrophysiology [4-6]. Typical 
neurobiology applications are ion channel screening, drug 
testing, developmental biology, micro-encephalograms 
(EEG), microelectroretinograms (ERG) and safety 
pharmacology studies. In the cardiac field, the typical 
applications are activation and excitation mapping, long-
term characterization of cell types (stem cells), 
measurement of conduction velocity and disease. 
The use of the electrodes as an actuation technique in 
microfluidics has also been demonstrated to implement 
highly definition fluidic transport with selective 
manipulating of suspended cells. The integration of 
microelectrodes with the right dimensions to generate the 
required electric field in microfluidic systems offers the 
potential of utilizing electrophoresis to handle, isolate or 
position individual cells with the goal of producing low 
cost instruments. Electrophoresis also proved to be a 
highly adaptable technique involving relatively simple 
hardware design and compatible with a wide range of 
analytic devices [7]. 
2 
 
Conductivity detection has also shown considerable 
interest in capillary electrophoresis where microelectrodes 
have been used to detect electro-inactive species. Organic 
acid, acetate, amino acid, explosives and peptides were 
detected by monitoring changes in the conductivity of the 
running buffer. In the case of direct contact conductivity 
detection, electrodes are in direct contact with the fluid, 
which offers an excellent contact with the sample but at 
the cost of the reduction of detector stability due to an 
increased possibility of fouling or degradation of the 
electrodes [8]. 
The increasing use of electrodes as actuators or as sensors 
has led to interest around the failure mechanisms and 
reliability of their physical structure. Consequently, the 
need for health monitoring in the electrode-based 
microfluidics is therefore essential to enhance the 
measurements, reduce false positives and false negatives 
and ensure the integrity of the recorded signal. 
Accelerating the uptake of these technologies is hence a 
core mission of numerous private and public funding 
bodies. Solutions for defining efficient non-destructive 
production test strategies, fault tolerant design features and 
integrated health monitoring are expected to be important 
contributions towards this goal [9,10]. 
The idea of Oscillation-Based-Test (OBT) for analogue 
integrated circuits was initially presented in [11] where the 
circuit under test is converted to a circuit that oscillates at a 
frequency that is a function of the material properties and 
structural integrity of the system. Faults in the circuit 
under test can be detected which normally cause a 
deviation of the oscillation frequency from its nominal 
value. The validity of this technique was verified through 
examples such as operational amplifiers and analogue-to-
digital converters. OBT has also been evaluated within 
MEMS-based systems through work on a monolithic 
magnetometer [12]. The natural frequency of the cantilever 
has been chosen to be the main input parameter to the test 
strategy. The tolerance band and detection range in the 
case of small deviations applied to technological process 
parameters have been assessed. The potential for using 
OBT in a DNA sensor array has been discussed in [13] and 
[14] as well where the modes of sensing and test can both 
be realised in an oscillator-based structure.  
The design, simulation and validation of an embedded 
health monitoring system for an electrode array sensor 
used in cell based bio assays have been proposed by [15]. 
The principle idea of this technique is to measure and 
compare the impedance of each sensing electrode. The 
impedance is measured using half-bridge circuit with the 
pass/fail metric based on the impedance ratio between each 
electrode against a reference under the assumption that the 
majority of the electrodes are fault-free. 
A study of the effect of geometry and surface termination 
on the morphological and chemical evaluation of 
polycrystalline silicon electrodes at applied bias and high 
relative humidity has been presented in [16]. Two poly-
silicon electrodes isolated from the substrate by a silicon 
nitride layer were considered for the corrosion test. During 
the experiment, anodic oxidation is observed on electrodes 
with native oxide layer. Damage to the cathode is also 
observed within 20 h under relative humidity value ≥89% 
when the anode to cathode area ration is greater than unity. 
From this work, understanding the corrosion mechanisms 
has led to enable the selection of surface passivation pre-
treatments to reduce the observed phenomenon. 
For digital droplet-based microfluidic systems, techniques 
for defect classification, test planning, and test resource 
optimization have been presented in [17], whilst in [18] 
both catastrophic and parametric faults have been detected 
by electro-statically controlling and tracking the motion of 
test droplets. The detection of these test droplets is through 
a simple RC oscillator formed by a pair of driving 
electrodes with the fluid between them acting as the 
dielectric. Furthermore, based on the test results, the 2-D 
EWOD (Electro-Wetting On Dielectric) arrays with open 
structures can be reconfigured in order to reallocate 
resources and avoid using the sites marked faulty.  
Another method based on Euler paths is proposed in [19], 
which maps a digital microfluidic biochip to an undirected 
graph where a test droplet is routed along the Euler path 
derived from the graph to pass through all the cells in the 
array. The dependability has also improved by using 
digital microfluidic logic gates. In [20, 21] fault diagnosis 
methods to locate a single defective cell and multiple 
rows/columns with defective cells in a digital microfluidic 
array have been presented. These methods utilize digital 
microfluidic (exclusive-OR/AND) gates to implement an 
output comparator. An efficient testing and diagnosis 
methodology for digital microfluidic biochips has also 
been proposed in [22]. This method is based on a 
partitioning technique that increases parallelism in testing 
and diagnosis by exploiting the available sources and sinks 
which supports the ability to detect and locate single as 
well as multiple faults in a microfluidic array. An excellent 
survey of research on design automation and test 
techniques for digital microfluidic biochips can be found 
in [23].  
The work carried out here is motivated by characterisation 
studies which have revealed that electrode degradation 
tends to be a key reliability issue in cell-based biosensors, 
conductivity sensors, and when used as actuators, where  
correction is not possible through manual cleaning [9,10]. 
Degraded electrodes tend to exhibit much lower signal-to-
noise ratio (SNR) or higher interface impedance that in 
both cases degrades the ability of the system to monitor 
cellular signals and bio-chemical processes, measure the 
accurate conductivity or moving the fluid to the right 
position. Monitoring key parameters or reliability 
indicators for these component parts in addition to the 
transportation and processing functions is hence an 
essential feature of future systems. This work 
complements the international effort to advance the field 
of embedded test for microfluidic systems and builds on 
3 
 
initial work on both an MEA (Micro-Electrode Array) 
structure and full bio-diagnostic system presented in 
[15,24,25]. This work will firstly focus on comparing the 
application of OBT on two demonstrators, MEA and 
electrode-based microfluidic mixing chip. The aim of these 
investigations is to consider the effect of the electrode’s 
size and structure, fluid permittivity and velocity on the 
measurements. Application the OBT at the system level is 
the second objective of this work where a microcontroller, 
analogue multiplexer, a test circuit and an LCD have been 
used to achieve fully controllable condition monitoring 
system for the MEA. 
The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 
briefly presents an electrical model at the circuit-level for 
the electrolyte-electrode interface. Section 3 describes the 
application of the OBT on the MEA and experimental 
results documented. The application of OBT on the second 
demonstrator, the electrode-based microfluidic mixing 
chip is presented in section 4 while OBT implementation 
at the system level is detailed in section 5 where a fully 
controllable condition monitoring technique is described. 
Finally, conclusions are drawn in section 6. 
2. Self Test Solution and Fault Modeling 
 
In using electrodes to sense either spontaneously generated 
extracellular potentials or to measure the impedance of 
target cells, the reliability indicator will be related to the 
fundamental signal coupling between the ion flow in the 
electrolyte and the electrode interface. Therefore, the 
electrical properties of the electrode-electrolyte interface 
are crucial parameters within fault-free and faulty systems. 
Analysis has however indicated that degradation of the 
sensing interface and the health status of bio-chemical 
species are not trivial parameters to monitor. 
 
To help understand the dependence of system performance 
on such physical defects, an electrical equivalent model 
may be used. An electrical model at the circuit-level for 
the interface has been developed and characterised in 
[15,24] which is based on the theoretical analysis of micro-
electrodes in [26]. This model is shown in Figure 1, where 
CEDL is the capacitance of the Electrical Double Layer, RCT 
the charge transfer resistance, ZW the Warburg impedance 
due to ion diffusion, ZP the impedance of the porous 
surface, RS the electrolyte spreading resistance and CX is 
the parasitic capacitance. 
 
Fig. 1 Circuit model for the electrode-electrolyte interface. 
3. Application of OBT on the MEA 
 
The model that has been developed for the electrode-
electrolyte interface has been characterised on an MEA 
platform as illustrated in Figure 2 [27]. This is a well-
accepted interface for recording the extracellular potentials 
from neuron networks or cardiac tissues [28]. The MEA 
has 60 sensing electrodes distributed on a square area of 
0.6 x 0.6 mm2 with the distance between neighbouring 
electrodes being 200 μm. Each sensing electrode has a 
diameter of 30 μm and is fabricated using high surface 
porosity material (TiN). The electrolyte used has a molar 
concentration of 120 mM. 
 
 
 
Fig. 2 Sensing electrodes site of the MEA (Reproduced 
from [27]). 
 
There are three potential mechanisms that can result in 
quality degradation of micro-electrodes according to the 
end-users. They are: 
• electrode degradation due to damage during the 
cleaning and preparation of the MEAs, 
• fouling of the electrodes by biological material that is 
not removed completely during cleaning, and 
• material loss of the electrode surface through ion loss 
into the surrounding liquid medium. 
All of these affect the electrode-electrolyte interface in the 
form of either physical damage, fouling from biological 
material deposits, or loss of solid material from the 
electrode surface. As the porous layer is located on top of 
the micro-electrodes and interfaced with the operational 
environment, it is logical to assume that the fault 
mechanism active will degrade the performance of the 
system through damage to the porous layer to some 
degree. 
When a solid (metal, semiconductor, insulator) is placed 
into an electrolyte (ionic solution), an electrified interface 
is formed due to chemical reactions where electrons are 
transferred between the solid and the electrolyte. The result 
is the formation of an electric field between the electrode 
and the electrolyte which stimulates further chemical 
reactions to take place. These reactions reach an 
equilibrium condition when the currents due to electron 
transfer to and from the solid are equal. The result of this 
process is the Electrical Double Layer (EDL). 
C
EDL
R
CT
Z
W
R
S
Z
P
C
X
4 
 
The model presented in Figure 1 has been shown to be 
useful for exploring the effect of surface degradation of the 
bio-electrodes under study. In many implementations of 
electrodes and electrode arrays, the value of EDL 
capacitance (CEDL) is a function of both expected 
biological processes (e.g. hybridisation) and degradation 
mechanisms such as fouling, contamination or electrolysis 
due to voltage bias. The electrode surface was made from 
high porosity material to increase the effect of the EDL. It 
is hence logical to expect that all relevant types of 
degradation that will affect the electrode structure will 
directly impact this layer. 
Looking in more detail at the capacitive component of the 
EDL, it can be shown that CEDL can be modelled by an 
equivalent network consisting of CH, the compact layer 
capacitance, CD, the diffusion capacitance, RD, the 
diffusion layer resistance and RB, the bulk resistance, as 
shown in Figure 3. Table 1 shows the calculated values for 
the EDL components. 
 
 
Fig. 3 Extension of the electrode model to include 
components of CEDL which can be replaced by CH, CD, RD 
and RB. 
Table 1 Calculated values of EDL components. 
Component Value 
CH 125 pF 
CD ≥758 pF 
RD 3 MΩ 
RB 1 KΩ 
 
The interface dominant capacitance of the EDL is CH and 
can be approximately expressed as 
1XAC roH εε=     (1) 
where εo is the permittivity of free space, εr is the relative 
permittivity of the electrolyte and X1 is the length of the 
compact capacitor (dominant capacitor), while A is the 
surface area of the electrode. As discussed above, damage 
to the porous layer on the surface of the sensing electrodes 
is an important physical defect which results from a range 
of electrochemical, bio-chemical and electromagnetic 
effects. It is also noted that the surface area of the 
electrode can be used to assess degradation because all key 
mechanisms will affect the active area and consequently 
change the dominant capacitance, CH. Based on the model 
above which describes the EDL at the electrode/electrolyte 
interface, the health status of the porous layer can be 
monitored as a function of frequency. 
To study the impact of the effective surface area of the 
electrode on the oscillation frequency of a test circuit 
theoretically, CEDL was inserted into the feedback of a 
standard oscillator structure as shown in Figure 4. 
 
Fig. 4 CEDL Integrated into the oscillation structure. 
The oscillator circuit used for characterisation of the 
effectiveness of OBT has used values for R1, R2, and R3 of 
1 M, 1 K and 100 KΩ respectively. With this set of values, 
the feedback voltage on the electrode is around ± 100 mV, 
and will be the same amplitude and the same duration but 
opposite polarity. Therefore, the accumulated charge will 
flow back to the op-amp circuit and not held at the 
electrode. The nominal value of CH is assumed to be 125 
pF, while CD, RD and RB are assumed to be constant 
because the change in electrode surface area has no effect. 
This oscillator outputs a square wave at a frequency of 
around 110 KHz in the fault-free case, and between 110 
KHz and 250 KHz dependant on the change in active area. 
To verify the oscillation-based self-test solution, an 
experiment on an MEA demonstrator has been carried out. 
In this experiment, the EDL capacitance is measured 
directly using a Wayne Kerr Precision Impedance 
Analyzer 6500. Measurements are conducted by 
connecting the impedance analyser to the target electrode 
and the ground electrode. In the set-up, the ground 
electrode serving as an internal reference is shorted with 
the electrolyte bath ground, and connected to the 
electronics ground in order to provide a common ground 
between the electronics and the bath. The capacitance is 
measured for the condition where the system is stimulated 
with a 50 mV input at 10 KHz. To demonstrate the effect 
of the electrode surface degradation on the EDL 
capacitance and to extract CEDL measurements at different 
levels of degradation, the electrode surface has been 
artificially damaged by repeatedly stimulating the 
electrodes with voltage pulses (1 Volt). Figures 5 and 6 
5 
 
show three-dimensional images for fault-free and 
artificially damaged electrodes respectively. These images 
have been captured using a Veeco Wyko NT100 White 
Light Interferometer. As can be seen from these figures, 
the effect of the stress pulses on the electrode surface area 
is the loss of large areas of the porous layer due to 
electrolysis. 
 
Fig. 5 3-D interactive image for fault-free electrode. 
 
Fig. 6 3-D interactive images for faulty electrode after 
application of stress pulses. 
This damage impacts the functionality of the surface 
porous layer and is the most widely reported degradation 
mechanism in typical applications. The EDL capacitance 
has been measured after specific time points within the 
stress program to extract the CEDL signature as a function of 
pulse time. The period of the stress pulse is 5 seconds with 
a stress program duration of 150 seconds. By stimulating 
the electrode with these pulses CEDL has decreased from 
around 180 pF to 55 pF, as a consequence, the oscillation 
frequency has increased to around 1.9 times  its fault-free 
value, fosc. Table 2 shows the change in the stress pulse 
time, CEDL and the oscillation frequency over the duration 
of the stress program. 
Table 2 The change in CEDL and the oscillation frequency 
with the stress pulse time. 
Stress pulse time 
(s)

frequency (KHz)

5 143.7 1.15 fosc 
10 136.1 1.18 fosc

35 91.7 1.48 fosc

4. Application of OBT on Electrode-based 
Microfluidic Mixing chip 
4.1 Experiment Setup 
To verify the effectiveness of the oscillation based 
technique on another demonstrator and characterize the 
effect of the electrode size, structure, material, and the 
moving fluid on the oscillation frequency, this technique 
has been applied on electrode-based microfluidic mixing 
chips. These chips are used to measure conductivity across 
pair of overlapped electrodes whilst running the solutions 
(0.1 molar HCl with 0.1 molar NaOH). A microfluidic 
platform capable to demonstrate different micro-scale 
fluidic processes such as mixing, separation or droplet 
generation has been used in this experiment. A schematic 
for experiment setup is shown in Figure 7. 
 
Fig. 7 Schematic of experiment setup. 
6 
 
The setup includes a common casing and base board, 
fluidic connectors, functional chip, pumps, the control 
software and an impedance analyzer. The casing is a 
standard 120×120×30mm cast-iron box (RS components) 
and prepared appropriately to accommodate the base board 
and the fluidic connectors. The base board includes the 
mechanism to establish fluidic seal between the channels 
in the base board and the functional chip. PMMA and SU-
8 have been used to fabricate the base board and the chips 
using standard lithographic and machining processes. 
WPI-Aladdin pumps have been used as external actuators 
that can provide precise and countable flow rate. 
LABVIEW software has been used to control the fluid 
while Coda-pins have been utilized to achieve electrical 
connection between the external electrical connector and 
the electrodes in the functional chip. 
The design of the mixing chip is shown in Figure 8 which 
illustrates the structure of the delay channel and the 
sensing chamber where two overlapped electrodes were 
fabricated and can be used to measure the fluid 
conductivity in the sensing chamber. 
 
Fig. 8 Design of the mixing chip. 
This chip was made from SU-8 and has two inlets A and 
B, and one outlet C. The inlets and outlet are connected to 
the base board using special connecters to achieve a fluidic 
seal between the channels on the base board and the chip. 
This mechanism allows the user to feed the chip with the 
required fluids at a certain flow rate using external pipes 
and pumps. The delay channel is used to deliver the delay 
required for the chemical reactions to take place. The 
dimensions of the delay channel are 150 m for the width, 
75 m for the depth, and around 9 cm for the length. The 
last part of the mixing chip is the sensing chamber, this 
chamber has a width of 2.35 mm and a length of 5 mm. In 
this chamber, two overlapped aluminium electrodes were 
fabricated using standard lithographic and machining 
processes. Each electrode has two parts, the dimensions of 
each part are 2.15 mm for the length and 0.25 mm for the 
width. 
In order to accomplish a bio-assay in the microfluidic 
platform, a control system to manage the operations on the 
bulk fluid is essential. The protocol involves HCl running 
at a flow rate 1 μL/min and NaOH at a flow rate 10 
μL/min, and then slowly step by step increasing HCl flow 
rate to match the NaOH. WPI-Aladdin pumps are 
connected to PC via RS232 and each of the pumps can be 
individually addressed. At the software level, the objective 
is to program the pumps to operate at a changeable 
velocity to monitor the fluid conductivity at different flow 
rates and complete the experiment. The codes are written 
in LABVIEW. As illustrated in Figure 9, fluid actuation 
functions consist of stacked commands that include setting 
the flow rate, selecting the pump, setting the diameter of 
the syringe and the direction of the pumping. 
 
 Fig. 9 Fluid control block diagram. 
A Wayne Kerr Precision Impedance Analyzer 6500 has 
been used to measure the conductance of the fluid in the 
sensing chamber between the overlapped electrodes. 
7 
 
Figure 10 shows measurements of the conductance 
spectrum whilst HCl is running at a flow rate 1 μL/min 
and NaOH is running at a flow rate 10 μL/min for the first 
case, and the conductance spectrum when the flow rate for 
both HCl and NaOH is 10 μL/min, the second case. From 
measurements, the highest conductance for the first case is 
around 25 mS at a frequency range around 365 KHz while 
the conductance has decreased to around 10 mS at the 
same frequency in the second case. 
 
Fig. 10 Conductance spectrums whilst HCl is running at a 
flow rate 1 μL/min and NaOH is running at a flow rate 10 
μL/min in the first case and when the flow rate for both 
HCl and NaOH is 10 μL/min in the second case. 
 
4.2 Effect of Electrode Degradation on the 
Oscillation Frequency 
To demonstrate the OBT on the microfluidic mixing chips 
and explore the degradation effect on Electrical Double 
Layer capacitance, experiment has been carried out. The 
electrode has been artificially damaged by repeatedly 
stimulating the electrode with voltage pulses (5 volt). 
Under these conditions the stimulating electrode behaves 
as a plate capacitor with accumulated charge maintained 
on the surface and hence time dependant degradation due 
to electrolysis. In these experiments, the EDL capacitance 
is measured directly using a Wayne Kerr Precision 
Impedance Analyzer 6500. 
Measurements are conducted by connecting the impedance 
analyzer to both electrodes. The EDL capacitance has been 
measured after definite time periods within the stress 
program to extract the CEDL signature as a function of 
pulse time. The period of the stress pulse is 20 seconds 
with stress program duration of 140 seconds. By 
stimulating the electrode with these pulses CEDL has 
decreased from around 70 nF to around 25 nF when HCl is 
running at flow rate of 1 μL/min and NaOH is running at 
flow rate of 10 μL/min while CEDL has decreased from 
around 45 nF to around 18 nF when the flow rate of both 
HCl and NaOH is 10 μL/min. The capacitance is measured 
for the condition where the chip is stimulated with a 50 
mV input at 10 KHz. Figure 11 depicts CEDL 
measurements at both cases. 
 
Fig. 11 Changing CEDL with the stress pulse time while 
HCl is running at a flow rate 1 μL/min and NaOH is 
running at a flow rate 10 μL/min in the first case and when 
the flow rate for both HCl and NaOH is 10 μL/min in the 
second case. 
From the results, although the effect of changing the 
permittivity and increasing flow rate of the fluid on the 
EDL capacitance measurement is clear, the range of 
changing EDL capacitance from fault-free case to the 
faulty one is still valid to convert the capacitance to 
frequency and monitor the status of the electrodes. Figures 
12 and 13 show the electrodes at fault-free case and faulty 
one respectively. 
 
Fig. 12 Fault-free electrode. 
 
Fig. 13 Faulty electrode. 
8 
 
The oscillation circuit in figure 4 has been used to 
characterize the effectiveness of the OBT and study the 
effect of the fluid flow rate and permittivity on the output 
frequency in the fault-free and faulty cases. The oscillation 
frequency has been measured after specific time periods 
within the stress program and with two different flow rates 
for the HCl (1 μL/min and 10 μL/min). Table 3 describes 
the oscillation frequency measurements for both cases.

From Table 3 and for the first case, HCl is running at 1 
μL/min and NaOH is running at 10 μL/min, the oscillation 
frequency has increased from the nominal value (fosc) at 
the fault-free case to around 2.47fosc at the faulty one. In 
the second case, when HCl is running at 10 μL/min and 
NaOH is running at 10 μL/min, the oscillation frequency 
has increased from the nominal value (fosc*) to around 2.32 
fosc*. The effect of increasing HCl flow rate and then 
changing the fluid permittivity on the oscillation frequency 
at the fault-free case is clear where the frequency has 
increase to around 1.12 of its value when the HCl flow rate 
has increased to 10 μL/min. The frequency range between 
the fault-free and the faulty case has also decreased due to 
the change in the permittivity and the drift velocity in the 
second case. 
In comparison between the Electrical Double Layer 
capacitance measurements at the fault-free and the faulty 
cases for the microfluidic mixing chips and the Micro 
Electrode Array, the following can be concluded: 1) The 
Electrical Double Layer capacitance has increased from 
the range of pF to the range of nF due to the significant 
increase in the electrode size hence surface area. 2) Both 
types of electrodes have demonstrated the same 
degradation mechanisms (Electrolysis due to stimulus 
pulses), and then the same behaviour and effect on the 
Electrical Double Layer capacitance. 3) The change in the 
CEDL from the fault-free case to the faulty one in the MEA 
electrodes is greater than the change in the mixing chips 
electrodes because of the high porosity and the micro-
folded structure of the MEA electrodes which physically 
increases the effective surface area. 
5. OBT Implementation at the System Level 
To achieve a fully controllable condition monitoring 
technique and verify the effectiveness of OBT in the 
system-level design, this approach has been applied to a 
device with 32 microelectrodes. The system consists of a 
microcontroller, an analogue multiplexer, a test circuit and 
an LCD. The whole system architecture is shown in figure 
14. The test circuit in figure 4 is used to convert the 
Electrical Double Layer capacitance to frequency.  An 
ADG732 analogue multiplexer (monolithic CMOS 32-
channel) has been used to connect the micro electrode 
array (32 electrodes from the MEA) to the oscillator test 
circuit. An Atmel megaAVR microcontroller serves as the 
control unit which monitors and synchronizes the system. 
The ATmega8A is a low-power CMOS 8-bit 
microcontroller based on the AVR RISC architecture 
which is programmed in “C” to control the operation of 
the test system. 
The ATmega8A is clocked by an external oscillator at 4 
MHz and has built-in timers and counters. Two general 
purposes Timer/Counters have been used to read pulses 
from the test circuit and to control the addressing of the 
analogue multiplexer. The first timer, TCNT0 
(Timer/Counter0) is a single channel 8-bit Timer/Counter 
module that can be used as a counter, frequency generator 
or external event counter. TCNT0 is used as an external 
event counter to read the external pulses form the test 
circuit on PORTD, pin 4 where these pulses increment the 
counter synchronously at each rising edge. 
 
Fig. 14 The system architecture. 
The second timer, TCNT1 (Timer/Counter1)  is a 16-bit 
Timer/Counter unit which allows accurate program 
execution  and signal timing measurement and can be used 
9 
 
as two independent output compare units, double buffered 
output compare register or clear timer on compare match. 
In this work, TCNT1 is used as an interrupt timer to time 
the collection of pulses and clear Counter0 before it 
overflows. This accurate timer is used to calculate the 
frequency of the pulses and hence the state of the electrode 
degradation. The following formula is used to calculate the 
binary reload value for the required time for TCNT1: 
ܴ݈݋ܽ݀௏௔௟௨௘ ൌ ሺ2௡ െ 1ሻ െ ቆ
௙ೀೄ಴
௉ೃಶೄ಴
ൗ
்௜௠௘௥௙௥௘௤_ு௭
ቇ                     (2) 
where n is the counter bit numbers, fOSC is the clock speed 
of the microcontroller (4MHz), PRESC is the pre-scalar for 
Timer1 (64) and Timerfreq_Hz is the sampling frequency 
which is 50 Hz. 
 
Fig. 15 The code-flow for the test algorithm. 
The overflow of TCNT1 is also responsible for 
incrementing the analogue multiplexer address after each 
cycle through PORTB. To monitor the measured 
frequency in real-time, an LCD in 4-bit mode is connected 
to PORTD, pins0-3, and an active-low input buttons are 
connected to PORTC, pins 0-3 for user selection. The 
microcontroller has been programmed to monitor the 
oscillation frequency, the analogue multiplexer address, 
health indication from the electrode and the reference 
frequency which is the frequency that all other frequencies 
from the test circuit are compared with and can be selected 
by the user, or based off of real-time test frequencies. 
Additionally, the microcontroller has been programmed to 
detect a “Bad Electrode” if the frequency of the target 
electrode is 1.4 times the reference frequency. The code 
flow for the microcontroller is described in Figure 15. 
To consider the stability of the reference frequency 
measurements, signature analysis for the fault-free 
electrode has been carried out where the effect of the noise 
and the feedback voltage from the test circuit on the 
oscillation frequency for a 90 min period. has been 
recorded (Figure 16). The data showed that the maximum 
deviation in the frequency is around ±1 %. 
 
Fig. 16 signature analysis for the fault-free electrode. 
To validate the test technique and illustrate the effect of 
the system parameters, an experiment on the MEA has 
been carried out. Thirty-two electrodes from the MEA 
were connected through the multiplexer to the test circuit. 
Different levels of degradation have been emulated by 
artificially damaging the surface area of ten electrodes 
with voltage stress pulses of 1 V amplitude and differing 
periods. The microcontroller has been programmed to 
increment output port B and a delay time of two seconds 
has been used to connect each electrode to the oscillator. 
Figure 17 shows the frequency measurements where the 
test technique has accurately distinguished the degraded 
electrodes and the level of the degradation. The fault-free 
frequency is denoted by fosc. 
10 
 
 
Fig. 17 Oscillation frequency measurements for 32 
electrodes. 
To demonstrate the effect of the analogue multiplexer 
input capacitance and resistance on the measurements, the 
oscillation frequency of ten electrodes (the same 
electrodes degraded by varying stress inputs) have been 
measured with and without the multiplexer. Single wires 
have been used in this experiment to avoid the coupling 
capacitance of the ribbon cable (Table 4). The effect of the 
self resistance, self capacitance and the coupling 
capacitance on the frequency measurements has also been 
demonstrated in a second experiment where the single 
wires have been replaced with ribbon cable. The 
equivalent circuit per unit length for the interface between 
the electrodes and the analogue multiplexer can be seen in 
Figure 18, where RS, CS, CC, and N are the self resistance, 
the self capacitance, the coupling capacitance, and the line 
numbers of the ribbon cable. 
 
Fig. 18 The per unit length electrical equivalent circuit for 
the ribbon cable. 
Table 4 shows the oscillation frequency measurements 
when single wires without the AMUX were used, and then 
when AMUX was inserted. The last column shows the 
measurements when the single wires have been replaced 
by ribbon cable.

The effect of the multiplexer input parameters (on-state 
capacitance and resistance) can be observed from the table 
where the normal oscillation frequency and modified 
frequencies due to different degradation levels have been 
shifted from their nominal values. The fault-free frequency 
has decreased by 7% while the full-range of the output 
frequency between the fault-free and the faulty cases has 
also decreased from 1.93% without AMUX to around 
1.82% with the AMUX.  
The ribbon cable parameters have also affected the 
measurements, where the fault-free oscillation frequency 
has decreased by 12%. The full-range measurements have 
also been limited by the self and coupling capacitances 
from 1.82% with single wires to around 1.75% with ribbon 
cable.  
 
Fig. 19 Temperature impact on the oscillation frequency 
measurements for fault-free and faulty electrodes. 
The impact of the temperature on the measurements and 
the test circuit has been considered in another experiment. 
The frequency readings for the fault-free electrode and 
three other electrodes that where degraded at different 
levels by applying voltage stress pulses of 1V amplitude 
11 
 
for different periods have been recorded for a temperature 
range from 10 oC to 55 oC (Figure 19). The measurements 
showed that the oscillation frequency decreased by around 
-3% of its nominal value for the fault-free and faulty 
electrodes when the temperature increased from 10 oC to 
55 oC. We can conclude that the difference in the 
measurements at each  temperature is constant and the 
final condition monitoring output will not be affected by 
the temperature because of the relative measurements. 
To check and validate the test technique for other types of 
defects, three electrodes were chosen to verify the 
effectiveness for short and open circuits. Electrodes 57 and 
58 have been shorted at the contact pins while an open 
circuit has been made by splitting the contact pin from the 
contact pad for electrode number 63. In the first case, the 
oscillation frequency has decreased to around 30% of its 
normal value because the effective surface area has 
physically doubled due to the short between the electrodes. 
In the second case, and due to the open circuit between the 
contact pin and the contact pad, the output frequency has 
increased to around 230% of its normal value. This 
suggests that this test technique can easily detect the faulty 
electrodes at different levels of degradation, and 
distinguish them from other different types of faults due to 
the frequency measurements and their deviation from the 
normal value. 
 
6. Conclusions 
In this paper, an oscillation based monitoring strategy 
presented in [24,25] has been applied to a fluidic chip with 
embedded electrodes for conductivity measurements and a 
system level implementation of an on-line condition 
monitoring structure defined. This technique is based on 
the sensitivity of the bio-fluidic interface capacitance to 
degradation, contamination and fouling. The design of the 
monitoring structure has been evaluated through physical 
characterisation involving data extracted for both the 
electrode-based microfluidic mixing chip and a multi 
electrode array used in [24,25] where a real time health 
monitoring technique has been presented. The technique 
provides an analogue value directly related to the 
degradation of the electrode, so has the ability to provide 
on-line degradation detection for a range of conditions on 
the electrode surface. 
The possibility of using this technique to detect other types 
of degradation needs to be considered and the validation of 
the on-line application of this solution to a normal 
operating MEA requires further study. 
Future work will involve further investigation into 
degradation mechanisms across range of applications. In 
addition, the further development of architectures where 
the integration of this technique into a higher level control 
system will support adaptability to ensure defective 
electrodes can be switched out of the system and the array 
reconfigured to maintain functionality. Of further 
importance is how electrode monitoring strategies can be 
integrated with other sensors and test solutions within a 
portable instrument.
